parts.content: I have a nice, hot apple pie to divide among my four friends. I have to decide how to split up the delicious dessert.
The people elect the best man or woman to be President.
You and I swap an old computer for a case of wine.
I steal your case of wine and drink it all.
I sign a minimum wage contract at the local Wal-Mart.
I download a pirated song.
Congress debates a tax reform.
A committee chooses the next round of Rhodes Scholars.
A judge offers lenience to a juvenile offender who pleads guilty.
I pay a lawn service to cut my yard.
I have a nice, hot apple pie to divide among my four friends. I have to decide how to split up the delicious dessert.
You and I swap an old computer for a case of wine.
I steal your case of wine and drink it all.
I sign a minimum wage contract at the local Wal-Mart.
I download a pirated song.
Congress debates a tax reform.
A committee chooses the next round of Rhodes Scholars.
A judge offers lenience to a juvenile offender who pleads guilty.
I pay a lawn service to cut my yard.
The people elect the best man or woman to be President.
Thou shalt not steal.
A panel determines the compensation to be paid to a victim of injury.
Polygamy is outlawed.
A bridge is ordered to be built.
If a man gouges another man’s eye, his eye shall be gouged in turn.

If an ox be a goring ox, and it shown that he is a gorer, and he do not bind his horns, or fasten the ox up, and the ox gore a free-born man and kill him, the owner shall pay one-half a mina in money.

When a man sells his daughter as a slave, she shall not go out as the male slaves do. If she does not please her master, who designated her for himself, then he shall let her be redeemed; he shall have no right to sell her to a foreign people, since he has dealt unfairly with her.
Thou shalt not murder.
Judging from the Code of Hammurabi, the Babylonian king had which kinds of power (please choose all that apply):
A king leads his army into battle.
A rule against killing slaves is enacted.
A murderer is sentenced to death.
Thou shalt not steal.
If a man gouges another man’s eye, his eye shall be gouged in turn.

If an ox be a goring ox, and it shown that he is a gorer, and he do not bind his horns, or fasten the ox up, and the ox gore a free-born man and kill him, the owner shall pay one-half a mina in money.

When a man sells his daughter as a slave, she shall not go out as the male slaves do. If she does not please her master, who designated her for himself, then he shall let her be redeemed; he shall have no right to sell her to a foreign people, since he has dealt unfairly with her.

People choose to pay hundreds of dollars for Oklahoma city Thunder tickets.
Wealth allows the rich to be generous.
You cannot infringe my right to the free exercise of my religious beliefs.
I have the right to make you write a long paper for this course.
I have a driver’s license to operate a motor vehicle in the great state of Oklahoma.
Even though it causes great offense, my right to free speech is nearly inviolable.
I have the right to ruin my computer if I want to.
You have the right to expect 75 minutes of instruction twice a week.
Property is necessary to raise my family.
Giving drug companies an exclusive patent for a certain timeframe incentivizes research and development.
A rising tide lifts all boats.
Communism grates against human nature.
I worked hard for my money!
High salaries encourage the smartest people to become doctors.
Taxing my earnings is akin to seizing my time.
My salary was negotiated fair and square with my employer.

Absence of coercion.
My college education allows me to do what I want in life.
Voting rights.
I am a master.
I am not a slave.
Though I don’t walk through a door, I could.
A government cannot place prior restriction on speech acts.
I have a right to bear arms.
A democratic assembly can restrict the ownership of assault weapons.
I have conquered my desire for ice cream.

The state cannot prevent Antigone from pursuing her religious beliefs.
The gods command families to bury their dead.
The king has the authority to make laws.
Not punishing a terrorist like Polynices will encourage more acts of terror.
Creon was the rightful successor to the throne.
It is right to bury one’s brother.
Antigone has the right to bury her brother as she pleases.
The safety of Thebes demands the non-burial of Polynices.

_____, then, is something final and self-sufficient, and is the end of action.
Nature, as we often say, makes nothing in vain, and man is the only animal whom she has endowed with the gift of _____.
Human good turns out to be activity of the soul in accordance with _____.

If, then, there is some _____ of the things we do, which we desire for its own sake, (everything else being desired for the sake of this), and if we do not choose everything for the sake of something else (for at that rate the process would go on to infinity, so that our desire would be empty and vain), clearly this must be the good and the chief good.

If all communities aim at some good, the _____ or political community, which is the highest of all, and which embraces all the rest, aims at good in a greater degree than any other, and at the highest good.
Further, the state is by nature clearly prior to the family and to the _____, since the whole is of necessity prior to the start.
It is clear, then, that some men are by nature free, and others _____.
He who has the power to take part in the deliberative or judicial administration of any state is said by us to be a _____ of that state.
Hence it is evident that the state is a creation of _____ ...
and that man is by nature a political _____.
_____, then, is something final and self-sufficient, and is the end of action.
Human good turns out to be activity of the soul in accordance with _____.

If, then, there is some _____ of the things we do, which we desire for its own sake, (everything else being desired for the sake of this), and if we do not choose everything for the sake of something else (for at that rate the process would go on to infinity, so that our desire would be empty and vain), clearly this must be the good and the chief good.

Further, the state is by nature clearly prior to the family and to the _____, since the whole is of necessity prior to the start.

Hence it is evident that the state is a creation of _____ ...
and that man is by nature a political _____.
Nature, as we often say, makes nothing in vain, and man is the only animal whom she has endowed with the gift of _____.

Hellenistic philosophy
Duty is paramount
Pleasure and pain are indifferents
All matter is composed of atoms
There is no afterlife
The gods are not concerned with humans
There is a rational order in the universe
Virtue is happiness
The aim of life is to achieve pleasure and avoid pain
Physical pleasures are dangerous
Justice is important
Justice is a convention

A parent disciplines her child.
A student respectfully calls his professor "Sir."
A lord collects rent from his serf.
A student pays tuition at her college.
A man sells his boat to his brother.
A pater familias lets his son use his farm.
A king issues an edict to his people.
A widow takes ownership of her late husband’s property through a probate proceeding.
A mother lets her sixteen year-old daughter borrow the car.
A freedman shows respect for his patron.

Some are by nature slaves.
None are by nature slaves.
God breathes life into the infant’s soul.
A newborn is a full human being.
Treat your inferiors as you would wish to be treated by your superiors.
There is nothing of equal value to the dignity of the human being.

Treat your inferiors as you would wish to be treated by your superiors.

Therefore if any two men desire the same thing, which nevertheless they cannot both enjoy, they become _____.

For the laws of nature, as justice, equity, modesty, mercy, and, in sum, doing to others as we would be done to, of themselves, without the terror of some power to cause them to be observed, are _____ to our natural passions, that carry us to partiality, pride, revenge, and the like.
Hereby it is manifest that during the time men live without a common power to keep them all in awe, they are in that condition which is called _____.

To understand political power right, and derive it from its original, we must consider, what state all men are naturally in, and that is, a state of perfect _____ to order their actions, and dispose of their possessions and persons, as they think fit, within the bounds of the law of nature, without asking leave, or depending upon the will of any other man.

For men being all the workmanship of one omnipotent, and infinitely wise maker; all the servants of one sovereign master, sent into the world by his order, and about his business; they are his _____, whose workmanship they are, made to last during his, not one another’s pleasure.
. . . and the life of man, solitary, poor, nasty, _____, and short.
The liberty of man, in society, is to be under no other legislative power, but that established, by _____, in the commonwealth.

I beleve that scarce any thing can be more absurdly said in natural Philosophy, than that which now is called Aristotle’s Metaphysics, nor more _____ to Government, than much of that he hath said in his Politics; nor more ignorantly, than a great part of his Ethics.
Though the earth, and all inferior creatures, be common to all men, yet every man has a property in his own _____: this nobody has any right to but himself.

It being by him removed from the common state nature hath placed it in, it hath by this labour something annexed to it, that excludes the common right of other men: for this labour being the unquestionable property of the labourer, no man but he can have a right to what that is once joined to, at least where there is enough, and as good, left in _____ for others.
Therefore if any two men desire the same thing, which nevertheless they cannot both enjoy, they become _____.
Hereby it is manifest that during the time men live without a common power to keep them all in awe, they are in that condition which is called _____.

To understand political power right, and derive it from its original, we must consider, what state all men are naturally in, and that is, a state of perfect _____ to order their actions, and dispose of their possessions and persons, as they think fit, within the bounds of the law of nature, without asking leave, or depending upon the will of any other man.

For men being all the workmanship of one omnipotent, and infinitely wise maker; all the servants of one sovereign master, sent into the world by his order, and about his business; they are his _____, whose workmanship they are, made to last during his, not one another’s pleasure.
. . . and the life of man, solitary, poor, nasty, _____, and short.
The liberty of man, in society, is to be under no other legislative power, but that established, by _____, in the commonwealth.

I beleve that scarce any thing can be more absurdly said in natural Philosophy, than that which now is called Aristotle’s Metaphysics, nor more _____ to Government, than much of that he hath said in his Politics; nor more ignorantly, than a great part of his Ethics.
Though the earth, and all inferior creatures, be common to all men, yet every man has a property in his own _____: this nobody has any right to but himself.

It being by him removed from the common state nature hath placed it in, it hath by this labour something annexed to it, that excludes the common right of other men: for this labour being the unquestionable property of the labourer, no man but he can have a right to what that is once joined to, at least where there is enough, and as good, left in _____ for others.

For the laws of nature, as justice, equity, modesty, mercy, and, in sum, doing to others as we would be done to, of themselves, without the terror of some power to cause them to be observed, are _____ to our natural passions, that carry us to partiality, pride, revenge, and the like.
The right to be secure against unreasonable searches and seizures.
The right to a trial by jury.
The right to not be tried for the same offence twice.
The right to bear arms.
The right to free exercise of religion.
The right to due process.
The right to protection against cruel and unusual punishment.
The right to free speech.
The right to unenumerated rights.

The right to a trial by jury.

The greatest improvements in the productive powers of labour, and the greater part of the skill, dexterity, and judgment, with which it is anywhere directed, or applied, seem to have been the effects of the _____.
By freedom is meant, under the present _____ conditions of production, free trade, free selling and buying.

It is the great multiplication of the productions of all the different arts, in consequence of the division of labour, which occasions, in a well-governed society, that universal _____ which extends itself to the lowest ranks of the people.

It is the necessary, though very slow and gradual, consequence of a certain propensity in human nature, which has in view no such extensive utility; the propensity to _____, barter, and exchange one thing for another.

As it is the power of exchanging that gives occasion to the division of labour, so the extent of this division must always be limited by the extent of that power, or, in other words, by the extent of the _____.
If among a nation of hunters, for example, it usually costs twice the labour to kill a _____ which it does to kill a deer, one _____ should naturally exchange for or be worth two deer.
The history of all hitherto existing societies is the history of _____ struggles.
The modern bourgeois society that has sprouted from the ruins of _____ society has not done away with class antagonisms.

Modern bourgeois society with its relations of production, of exchange and of property, a society that has conjured up such gigantic means of production and of exchange, is like the _____, who is no longer able to control the powers of the nether world whom he has called up by his spells.
The proletarians have nothing to lose but their _____.

The greatest improvements in the productive powers of labour, and the greater part of the skill, dexterity, and judgment, with which it is anywhere directed, or applied, seem to have been the effects of the _____.

It is the great multiplication of the productions of all the different arts, in consequence of the division of labour, which occasions, in a well-governed society, that universal _____ which extends itself to the lowest ranks of the people.

It is the necessary, though very slow and gradual, consequence of a certain propensity in human nature, which has in view no such extensive utility; the propensity to _____, barter, and exchange one thing for another.

As it is the power of exchanging that gives occasion to the division of labour, so the extent of this division must always be limited by the extent of that power, or, in other words, by the extent of the _____.
If among a nation of hunters, for example, it usually costs twice the labour to kill a _____ which it does to kill a deer, one _____ should naturally exchange for or be worth two deer.
The history of all hitherto existing societies is the history of _____ struggles.
The modern bourgeois society that has sprouted from the ruins of _____ society has not done away with class antagonisms.

Modern bourgeois society with its relations of production, of exchange and of property, a society that has conjured up such gigantic means of production and of exchange, is like the _____, who is no longer able to control the powers of the nether world whom he has called up by his spells.
The proletarians have nothing to lose but their _____.
By freedom is meant, under the present _____ conditions of production, free trade, free selling and buying.
Certainly the affirmative pursuit of one’s convictions about the ultimate mystery of the universe and man’s relation to it is placed beyond the reach of law.
What is this freedom?
There is no reasonable ground for interfering with the liberty of person or the right of free contract by determining the hours of labor in the occupation of a baker.
It may be assumed that the minimum wage is fixed in consideration of the services that are performed in teh particular occupations under normal conditions.
It is also to be noted that the compulsory flag salute and pledge requires affirmation of a belief and an attitude of mind.
We are dealing here with the formative period in the development of citizenship.

There is no mysticism in the American concept of the State or of the nature or origin of its authority. We seet up government by consent of the governed, and the Bill of Rights denies those in power any legal opportunity to coerce that consent.
It is a question of which of two powers or rights shall prevail – the power of the State to legislate or the right of the individual to liberty of person and freedom of contract.

In other words, the proprietors lay down the rules and the laborers are practically constrained to obey them. In such cass, self-interest is often an unsafe guide, and the legislature may properly interpose its authority.

We are dealing here with the formative period in the development of citizenship.

There is no mysticism in the American concept of the State or of the nature or origin of its authority. We seet up government by consent of the governed, and the Bill of Rights denies those in power any legal opportunity to coerce that consent.
It is a question of which of two powers or rights shall prevail – the power of the State to legislate or the right of the individual to liberty of person and freedom of contract.

In other words, the proprietors lay down the rules and the laborers are practically constrained to obey them. In such cass, self-interest is often an unsafe guide, and the legislature may properly interpose its authority.
